channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96; Was World’s Longest-Reigning Monarch
item.description: She ruled over Britain for nearly seven decades, unshakably committed to the rituals of her role amid epic social and economic change and family scandal.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in 2012.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II: A Life in Photos
item.description: Elizabeth took her first steps in a world we recognize only from sepia photographs, and became Britain’s longest-reigning monarch. Here are a selection of images from her life.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mona Boshnaq
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Trump’s Post-Election Fund-Raising Comes Under Scrutiny by Justice Dept.
item.description: A federal grand jury has issued subpoenas seeking information about Save America PAC, which was formed as Donald J. Trump promoted baseless assertions about election fraud.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Adam Goldman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fact that federal prosecutors are seeking information about Save America PAC is a significant turn in a sprawling investigation into the roles that Donald J. Trump and his allies played in trying to overturn the 2020 election.

item.title: Garland Faces Tough Calls in Weighing Response to Trump Ruling
item.description: As the department decides whether to appeal the ruling on a special master, it is balancing a desire to speedily resolve the inquiry with the need to limit an expansive view of executive power.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Until the ruling, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland and his top officials had controlled the public narrative surrounding the inquiry.

item.title: Ex-U.S. Attorney’s Book Addresses Pressure to Help Trump Causes
item.description: Geoffrey S. Berman, who headed the Manhattan office, says in a book the Justice Department pushed cases, against John Kerry and others, to help Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s tweets set off pressure on prosecutors, according to the former top prosecutor’s book.

item.title: Shock Waves Hit the Global Economy, Posing Grave Risk to Europe
item.description: The threat to Europe’s industrial might and living standards is particularly acute as policymakers race to decouple the continent from Russia’s power sources.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin last Thursday, the first day a new German energy conservation law went into effect. Under the law, monuments may no longer be illuminated at night.

item.title: Liz Truss, New UK Leader, Lays Out Energy Price Cap Plan
item.description: Facing severe economic headwinds, Prime Minister Liz Truss announced emergency measures on her third day in office to freeze gas and electricity rates.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss campaigned on a message of tax cuts and deregulation, which made the price freeze a striking ideological reversal.

item.title: Fed Chair Powell Signals Interest Rates to Remain High to Fight Inflation
item.description: The Federal Reserve chair has taken a hawkish tone in recent appearances, seeking to underscore the central bank's commitment to bringing down prices.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, speaking in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Bannon Surrenders to Face New York Indictment in Wall Case
item.description: Stephen K. Bannon, whom former President Donald J. Trump pardoned, has been entangled in what prosecutors have said was a crowdfunding fraud scheme.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius, Jonah E. Bromwich and Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: The charges against Stephen Bannon are believed to involve an effort to build a border wall.

item.title: Memphis Shooting Spree Leaves 4 Dead
item.description: The police arrested a 19-year-old who they said had carried out a string of shootings. Residents had been urged to stay indoors during the search.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Houston Cofield for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police in Memphis flooded the city on Wednesday in pursuit of a gunman who killed four people.

item.title: David Shor, a Data Guru for Democrats, Throws One Last Bash
item.description: Political operatives, techies and the nightlife crowd mix at a Burning Man-style party hosted by an influential strategist who gained new friends and enemies after a tweet.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Bernstein
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times
item.media:description: The political consultant David Shor, center, hosted an end-of-summer party at his Lower Manhattan loft on Saturday night.

item.title: 2022 NFL Season Preview: What to Expect From Every Team
item.description: The Broncos bet big on Russell Wilson, the Packers went all in on defense and Tom Brady endures. But did any N.F.L. team position itself to ascend higher than the Los Angeles Rams this season?
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson, Joe Drape, Jesus Jiménez, Emmanuel Morgan, Kris Rhim and Jenny Vrentas

item.title: CIA Director Said Putin’s Ukraine Invasion Looks Like a ‘Failure’
item.description: William J. Burns said that counterattacks in the south and northeast showed that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had underestimated Ukraine’s capacity for combat.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers preparing to fire toward Russian positions in the Kharkiv region in July.

item.title: Alcaraz Beats Sinner in Late, Late US Open Match
item.description: The Spanish teenager needed five sets and more than five hours to reach the semifinals in a match that ended shortly before 3 a.m. in New York.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz on Thursday after his victory over Jannik Sinner in a quarterfinal match at the U.S. Open.

item.title: When Weird Al Yankovic Met Daniel Radcliffe, Things Got … Well, You Know
item.description: For their decidedly nonfactual rock biopic, the pop-music parodist and the “Harry Potter” star found themselves on the same wavelength.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m amazed the lawyers let us get away with this movie, frankly,” Yankovic said.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Leaves Behind a Radically Different Britain
item.description: She helped obscure a bloody history of decolonization whose proportions and legacies have yet to be adequately acknowledged.
item.dc:creator: Maya Jasanoff
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Who Will Control the Senate? The Answer Could Be in an Email.
item.description: Do you think your newfound popularity has something to do with politics?
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins

item.title: The Man Who Won the Republican Party Before Trump Did
item.description: Pat Buchanan knew that “the greatest vacuum in American politics is to the right of Ronald Reagan.”
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hemmer
item.media:description: Pat Buchanan campaigns with a Winchester rifle in 1996.

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Care
item.description: It can be a safe haven for our most vulnerable children.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Jordan Rowland and the New York Public Library, via Unsplash; and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: What Antarctica’s Disintegration Asks of Us
item.description: What if we saw Antarctica as a harbinger of transformation rather than doom?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rush
item.media:description: Icebergs in the Southern Ocean.

item.title: Live by the Trump, Die by the Trump
item.description: Republicans’ amoral alliance with the former president may well be a midterms curse.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni

item.title: Pakistan’s Vulnerability to Disaster Was Through the Roof. Then Came the Floods.
item.description: The Pakistani climate scientist Fahad Saeed on why he’s scared.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: Covid’s Toll on Native Americans
item.description: Covid’s death toll in Indigenous communities has no modern precedent.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez and Ashley Wu

item.title: Is California Jump-Starting the Electric Vehicle Revolution?
item.description: A new rule aiming to reduce emissions could set off a major shift in the automobile industry.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Michael Simon Johnson, Will Reid, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Interstate 10 in California. On the way to its ultimate goal, the state will require that 35 percent of new passenger vehicles sold by 2026 — and 68 percent by 2030 — produce no carbon emissions.

item.title: 4 Types of Voters We’re Watching in the Midterms
item.description: For our podcast The Run-Up, Astead Herndon and his team are talking with voters of all stripes. For many of them, frustration with politics is tied to their worries about democracy.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Midterm elections are typically a judgment of the president or party in power, but this year’s political landscape could be different.

item.title: We Want to Hear About Your Experience With Egg Freezing
item.description: The Times is looking for stories from readers.
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: Bernard Shaw, CNN’s Lead Anchor for 20 Years, Dies at 82
item.description: He covered the gulf war and the protests in Tiananmen Square and became one of the first Black anchors of a prime-time network news program.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: The CNN anchor Bernard Shaw on the set in 2000.

item.title: Twilight of Entrepreneurs in China as More Leave the Country
item.description: Two of China’s best-known entrepreneurs, Pan Shiyi and Zhang Xin, stepped down from their top jobs at the real estate development company they built.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Visual China Group via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Chinese entrepreneurs Pan Shiyi, left, and Zhang Xin quit this week as chairman and chief executive, respectively, of their real estate empire, Soho China.

item.title: Saudi-Tied Tournament Causes Push to Void Trump’s N.Y.C. Golf Contract
item.description: City Council leaders asked Mayor Eric Adams to end the Trump Organization’s contract to run a city-owned golf course in the Bronx and to cancel a tournament next month.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Alan Blinder
item.category: Trump Golf Links at Ferry Point
item.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams is being asked to reconsider his decision not to challenge the Trump Organization’s decision to host the golf event.

item.title: What Is Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma? Jane Fonda’s Cancer Diagnosis
item.description: Jane Fonda recently revealed that she was diagnosed with the cancer. Doctors explained the symptoms, testing and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Can You Have Alcohol After the Covid Vaccine and Booster Shot?
item.description: Moderate drinking is unlikely to impair the immune response to the Covid vaccine, but heavy drinking might.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor

item.title: How to Prevent Memory Loss
item.description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.category: The Complete Guide to Memory: The Science of Strengthening Your Mind (Book)

item.title: What Are Neti Pots and How Do They Work?
item.description: Nasal rinsing has been used for thousands of years to relieve sinus inflammation, congestion, allergy symptoms and more. Here’s what the evidence says.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan

item.title: How to Handle Returning to the Office
item.description: The gossip, the loud talker and the nosy colleague are all manageable with the right mind-set.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: The Legend on Lexington
item.description: It’s where Sean Combs got his start in fashion, Sarah Jessica Parker bought her Calvins and André Leon Talley rode the escalator with Givenchy. Memories of 150 years at Bloomingdale’s.
item.dc:creator: Ruth La Ferla and Guy Trebay
